newsitem.title: UK: N.Sea April crudes seen recovering, but March weak.
newsitem.headline: N.Sea April crudes seen recovering, but March weak.

text.p: Improved refining margins over the last week were seen boosting differentials for April-loading North Sea crudes, but unsold supplies of March Brent were keeping the benchmark grade under pressure, traders said.

A Statfjord loading April 1-3 fetched Dated Brent +10 cents, up from the last reported trade at Dated Brent evens. The seller said other deals done on a p+c basis also indicated a slight recovery in differentials.
A Gullfaks C loading March 26-28 traded at Dated Brent +7 cents.

"Refining margins improved over the last week and people had the impression that the market (for Norwegian grades) was longer than it is. I think (refiners) went into their Monday morning meetings and had revised ideas about throughputs," said a Norwegian producer.
Margins for a complex Rotterdam refinery averaged $1.36 a barrel last week, up from the sub-$1 levels seen at the beginning of the month.

A wet Brent loading March 27-29 at April Brent -80 cents, and a March 26-28 moved at April -81 cents. There were two April Brents passing through the paper chains on Monday, and several cargoes of March Brent were still unsold, traders said.
CFDs for this week recovered slightly to talk at May Brent -57/-45, with the roll into next week traded at +10 cents.
Outright April Brent was trading five cents down at around $19.69 a barrel on the IPE screen at 1638 GMT.
